simplesect.para: At cocktail parties, people no longer give me blank looks when I tell them I write free software. "Oh, yes, Open Source — like Linux and all that stuff?" they say. I nod eagerly in agreement. The terms free software and open source are largely interchangeable, though the latter seems to be in wider use among non-programmers. "Yes, exactly! That's what we work on," I say.

Over the last couple of decades, Free Software has gone from being an obscure, mostly unfunded sideline in the software development world, to a [todo]... but, although people now know what it is, they don't know how it works. The most common questions are: "But how do you get paid?" and "Who makes the decisions in these projects?".

para.remark: Describe target audience(s), and assumed reader background. (As in, the reader should know what the terms "source code" and "commit" mean, even if doesn't write code, etc.) Also: explain that to an experienced free software programmer, much of this book will seem obvious, trite, and boring. Point out how wide the gap is and how you don't need the bridge if you're already on the other side.

Explain very briefly how the two terms FS and OSS are synonymous, though different in emphasis; talk about how people got confused by "free", mention the open source consortium. Point out that the term "open source" gives the useful contrasting term "closed source", which is much more descriptive than "non-free". But this initial mention of FS/OSS terminology should be very short, only a paragraph or so. Leave the rest for the History section in Chapter 1, .

Andy's note about this bit said: "Keep the discussion of free and open source to one or two sentences. Basically, say they refer to pretty much the same software but stress different aspects of the movement. Then refer readers to Chapter 1." Agreed. Am leaving this tweak for later, because the style and density of the one or two sentences here will depend partly on what's to come.

Anamoly: "closed-source" is almost always hyphenated, "open source" is not. Dunno why this is, but at least it should be acknowledged. Also, note how "commercial" is not being used as an antonym for "free / open source" here: plenty of free software projects are commercial in intent. The important difference is proprietary vs non-proprietary, not commercial vs non-commercial.
(O'Reilly probably has boilerplate for this section.)
Andy says: "Copy and amend bolerplate from another book." Will do.

Might want to note why a URL is sometimes given and sometimes not. Basically, it's a matter of convenience. When offering a quote, for example, it's best to give the actual web page. But a mention of a project may or may not call for a URL, depending on the context. The general principle is that if the obvious Google search would quickly lead to the item in question, then there's no point giving the URL, unless it would be very easy & unobtrusive to do so.
